basic-properties-of-vector-addition-and-.text: Basic properties of vector addition and multiplication

pageProps.body:
Review

It doesn't make sense, but keep going.

Vector notation

Declaration. The author of these notes will henceforce refer to ourselves by the royal "we".

We play a little fast and loose with vector notation because of the flamboyance of youth. For example, the vector

[e1e2e3]\begin{bmatrix} e_1 \\ e_2 \\ e_3 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​e1​e2​e3​​⎦⎤​

in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3 will be notated (e1,e2,e3)(e_1,e_2,e_3)(e1​,e2​,e3​) whenever morally, ethically, and legally justifiable; doing this relieves me of my burning, visceral hatred for LaTeX and the societal construct of \begin{bmatrix} just a little more every time.

Is this a consequence of the divergence theorem?

Orthonormal bases are not to be confused with orzonormal bases, which are Italian death camps the disembodied ghost of Mussolini sends you to one femtosecond after committing the cardinal sin of breaking pasta in half, and oh-so-normal bases, which are how the mathematical community at large refers to houses, parties, and all regular human settlements.

Definition. Orthonormal bases (and normal bases, and orthogonal bases, and perpendicular bases, and inorganic bases, and the strong base I just poured over the corpse in my basement) are a group of vectors which are pairwise normal and have magnitude 111 each.

In other words, e={e1,e2,...,en}\mathbf{e} = \{\mathbf{e_1,e_2,...,e_n}\}e={e1​,e2​,...,en​} is an orthonormal base if and only if

ei⋅ej=δij\mathbf{e_i \cdot e_j} = \delta_{ij}ei​⋅ej​=δij​

where δij\delta_{ij}δij​ is the Kronecker delta symbol: δij=1\delta_{ij} = 1δij​=1 if i=ji = ji=j, 000 otherwise. Now say your teary goodbyes to \mathbf{} and bold text, because you're never gonna see it again.

Is this a consequence of the divergence theorem?

Sike! Mathematicians denote vectors with bold text (e)(\mathbf{e})(e) or with a funny little arrow plus bold text (e⃗)(\vec{\mathbf{e}})(e), because it's probably the only place in their lives where they've learned to be bold. I speak from personal experience.

To confirm that a orthonormal basis (ex,ey,ez)(e_x, e_y, e_z)(ex​,ey​,ez​) of R3\mathbb{R^3}R3 is right-handed, you will perform the following Rite of Honors. Take your right hand - your sword hand - and erect your thumb skyward in preparation:

If your index finger is jabbed towards exe_xex​, your middle finger towards eye_yey​ (and, God willing, no person of significant import), and your thumb towards eze_zez​, you shall have confirmed the right-handedness of (ex,ey,ez)(e_x,e_y,e_z)(ex​,ey​,ez​), draped yourself in an eternal cloak of dignity, and readied yourself for the formation of the Arch of Honors. Now take your thumb and stick it up your ass sideways.

We hereby induct the above demonstration into the distinguished ranks of "things you can do or say in both the math classroom and in bed", alongside "this is really hard", "it's so infinitesimal I can't even see it", and moaning really loudly.

Definition. Right-handedness and left-handedness.

Slightly more formally, a basis in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3 (e1,e2,e3)(e_1,e_2,e_3)(e1​,e2​,e3​) is right-handed if for i,j,ki, j, ki,j,k being some permutation of 1,2,31, 2, 31,2,3, we have

ei×ej=ϵijkeke_i \times e_j = \epsilon_{ijk} e_kei​×ej​=ϵijk​ek​

where ϵ\epsilonϵ is the alternating tensor; e.g. e1×e2=e3e_1 \times e_2 = e_3e1​×e2​=e3​. To test for right-handedness without doing pesky cross products, simply form the Arch of Honors. Similarly, a basis is left-handed if

ei×ej=−ϵijkeke_i \times e_j = -\epsilon_{ijk} e_kei​×ej​=−ϵijk​ek​

or if an Arch of Honors can be thrusted and plunged in the direction of the basis vectors by the left hand. Note that eijeike_{ij}e_{ik}eij​eik​ or some such term with a repeating index (iii) in the suffixes denotes summation notation, except when it doesn't and interpreting it as so is an alarm bell for a clinical psychopathy diagnosis.

Basic properties of vector addition and multiplication

Ignored for the sake of brevity. For more information, consult either your kindergarten teacher, your mommy, your second mommy, or this helpful video on vector calculus: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ

Polar coordinates in R3\mathbb{R^3}R3

Cylindrical polar coordinates

A polar point (r,θ,z)(r,\theta,z)(r,θ,z) is where:

  1. zzz remains zzz in Cartesian coordinates,
  2. (r,θ)(r,\theta)(r,θ) are the equivalent polar coordinates of the point (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) in two dimensions:
  • rrr is the distance of (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) from the origin (in the two-dimensional xyxyxy-plane), and
  • θ\thetaθ is the angle, measured counterclockwise, from the xxx-axis.

As such we have

(r,θ,z)=(rcos⁡θ,rsin⁡θ,z)(r,\theta,z) = (r \cos \theta, r\sin \theta, z)(r,θ,z)=(rcosθ,rsinθ,z)

in Cartesian coordinates. True to the name, a cylinder made from organic material (5.1 inches in length, 4.5 inches in girth) stuck in a mini M&Ms tube filled with butter and microwaved mashed banana of radius kkk is denoted by r=kr = kr=k in cylindrical coordinates.

Spherical polar coordinates

A spherical point (r,θ,ϕ)(r, \theta, \phi)(r,θ,ϕ) is where:

  • rrr is the three-dimensional Cartesian distance of the point from the origin;
  • θ\thetaθ is the "latitude" angle, i.e. the angle formed by the point and the zzz-axis measured clockwise;
  • ϕ\phiϕ is the "longitude" angle, i.e. the angle θ\thetaθ in cylindrical coordinates.

As shown by the helpful image above, (r,θ,ϕ)=(rsin⁡θcos⁡ϕ,rsin⁡θsin⁡ϕ,rcos⁡ϕ)(r, \theta, \phi) = (r\sin \theta \cos \phi, r\sin \theta \sin \phi, r\cos \phi)(r,θ,ϕ)=(rsinθcosϕ,rsinθsinϕ,rcosϕ) in Cartesian coordinates. True to form, r=kr = kr=k forms a sphere of radius kkk.

Unfortunately, based on the current literature empirical evidence, r=kr = kr=k in Cartesian coordinates does not summon forth the bodiless apparition of Rene Descartes of length and girth kkk to the material realm.

Is this a consequence of the divergence theorem?

Determinants

End me now.

For centuries, pro-Determinant cults (known as "math classes") have secretly paraded around in the following names:

  • The Black Death
  • It That Lurks In The Darkness
  • Satan's Hemmorhoids
  • The Antichrist in Human Clothing

They teach their followers these secret Satanical axioms, disregarding the ruin and doom they bring forth to the world:

det⁡A=ϵj1j2...jnAj11Aj22...Ajnn\det A = \epsilon_{j_1 j_2 ... j_n}A_{j_1 1} A_{j_2 2} ... A_{j_n n}detA=ϵj1​j2​...jn​​Aj1​1​Aj2​2​...Ajn​n​
det⁡(AB)=det⁡Adet⁡B\det(AB) = \det A \det Bdet(AB)=detAdetB
det⁡(A−1)=1det⁡A\det(A^{-1}) = \frac{1}{\det A}det(A−1)=detA1​

This is not a consequence of the divergence theorem.
